- I knew right away it wasn’t legit, but it’s hard to say exactly how. I’ve run into this problem before ; I have a lot of experience looking at space images, and you just get a sense of what’s real and what isn’t. This one screams fake. The landscape color is a bit too saturated for Mars * . The sky’s the wrong color. The clouds are too numerous, the wrong color as well, and they have that "rendered by software" look to them. Reference: https://www.discovermagazine.com/the-sciences/an-unreal-mars-skyline published on 2012-08-10 15:59:25

- Interestingly, fiddling with some of software I have that displays solar system planetary positions, I found that a couple of years ago (mid-2010) the view from Mars right after sunset would show Venus, Earth, and Jupiter lined up something like that. Had you been on Mars looking west you would’ve seen something very much like the vista in the picture. Thing is, had one of the rovers taken this picture, it would’ve been all over the web at the time … including here on Bad Astronomy. I wouldn’t have passed up the chance to post a picture that cool. Reference: https://www.discovermagazine.com/the-sciences/an-unreal-mars-skyline published on 2012-08-10 15:59:25
correction_response:
This tweet is misleading. The image of Earth, Venus, and Jupiter as seen from Mars is not a real photograph. It's likely a computer-generated image using planetarium software, recreating an event that happened eleven years ago. The Perseverance rover, which recently landed on Mars, has not captured such an image. The claims of such a photo being real have been debunked multiple times. For real photos from the Perseverance rover, you can visit NASA's website.

refute_evidences: - Since NASA 's Perseverance rover touched down on the surface of Mars last week, social media users have claimed the rover took a photo of Earth, Venus, and Jupiter lined up in Mars' skyline. But these claims are false. Reference: https://www.newsweek.com/earth-venus-jupiter-seen-mars-nasa-mars-perseverance-photo-fake-1571688 published on 2021-02-24 11:30:24

- This is exactly what you see when you use planetarium software on a computer to display the sky. Programs like Starry Night, SkySafari, and so on will put the cardinal directions (north, south, and so on) along the horizon to indicate what direction you’re looking. And many of them will display the appearance of the sky from other planets. It’s clear that’s what we have here: a rendered view from Mars using planetarium software. Reference: https://www.discovermagazine.com/the-sciences/an-unreal-mars-skyline published on 2012-08-10 15:59:25

- The image was probably computer-generated using planetarium software in order to recreate an event in which the three planets did indeed align from Mars' perspective. But that happened eleven years ago, and no-one got a photo of it.
